surface.text: Between 1980 and 2010, Madagascar was struck by 35 cyclones and floods, five periods of severe droughts, five earthquakes and six epidemics, threatening the uniquely diverse flora and fauna of the island.

In Arctic Siberia, rising temperatures have caused intense wildfires across the region’s boreal forests and tundra. When the tundra, which is a carbon sink, burns it releases more carbon emissions than burning forests.
India has suffered increasingly frequent and extreme heatwaves since the start of the century. In 2015, over 2,400 people died in a heatwave and such events have become more common.
In Uttarakhand, in the Himalayas, a deadly flood, caused by a breaking glacier, killed around 140 people in 2021. Global warming will cause mountain temperatures to rise twice as fast as the average.

Over the last 20 years, California experienced more years of drought than it did without drought. The most severe period, between January 2014 and January 2017, led to a severe water deficit in both the soil and underground aquifers.
The northernmost inhabited Arctic town, Longyearbyen on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard, saw a new record temperature of 21.7°C on 25 July 2020, compared to a July average of 5.9°C.

ocean.text: In September 2020, Arctic sea ice shrank to the second-lowest extent ever recorded (3.709 million square kilometres). A Siberian heatwave accelerated the ice retreat along the Arctic Russian coast, in particular from late June.

In March 2020, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef, home to the world’s largest collection of coral reefs, suffered a third mass coral bleaching event in five years due to increasingly warmer temperatures, recorded in February.

fire.text: In Australia, the 2019-2020 wildfire season was the worst on record, burning 18.3 million hectares by mid-January, causing loss of life, homes, livelihoods and the reported deaths of a billion animals.

In the western United States, following record-breaking high temperatures in August 2020, lightning strikes from severe thunderstorms ignited fires in California, Oregon and Washington, consuming 2 million hectares and leaving at least 40 people dead.

In Arctic Siberia, exceptional and prolonged heat fuelled unprecedented fires during the summer of 2020. Satellite images from Europe's Sentinel 3 showed that the wildfires covered a width of about 800 kilometres.

In 2015, massive wildfires ravaged Indonesia, scorching 2.6 million hectares and producing a toxic haze that blanketed neighboring Singapore and Malaysia. Indonesia suffered $16 billion in economic losses, according to the World Bank. Fires set to clear land often spiral out of control, particularly during the dry season.

Canada suffered the worst wildfire season on record in 2018, with 16,000 people evacuated as 2,117 wildfires filled the skies of western Canada with smoke. Weather was a key driver with late July bringing record-breaking temperatures and severe lightning.

In 2020, Brazil’s Amazon rainforest experienced its worst outbreak of fires in a decade, with blazes increasing 13 per cent in the first nine months compared to 2019. Scientists said the dry season was particularly severe partly because of warming in the tropical North Atlantic Ocean, which pulled moisture away from South America.
